Situation1: They make weekly phone calls to update their parents on life events and ask about their well-being.
Expectation2: Live according to Christian moral values and ethics
Situation2: They encounter choices where Christian ethics become more relevant
Story: Every Sunday evening, I call my parents, just as I always have. It’s our ritual—my way of showing I care, of being a good daughter. Tonight, though, my heart pounds as I stare at my phone. Earlier today, I witnessed a friend at church being unfairly treated by someone in our community. As a Christian, I know I should stand up for what’s right, speak the truth, and support those who are wronged. But my parents have always told me to avoid conflict, to keep my head down and not get involved in other people’s problems. I know if I tell them what happened, they’ll worry, maybe even scold me for thinking about getting involved. But if I stay silent, I feel like I’m betraying my faith and my friend. The phone rings in my hand, my parents’ expectations and my Christian values pulling me in opposite directions. I close my eyes, torn between being the dutiful daughter they want and the Christian I strive to be.
